headline: Welfare Sanctions Bill Passes Final Reading Amid Fierce Opposition Over Pay Equity and Infrastructure Plans
summary: Parliament was dominated by contentious legislation today, as the Government's bill to introduce tougher welfare sanctions passed its final reading against a storm of opposition. Meanwhile, a new bill to fast-track land acquisition for infrastructure was introduced, and ministers faced a barrage of questions over the recent cancellation of 33 pay equity claims affecting thousands of workers.

topicSummaries.topic: Welfare Sanctions Bill Passes Third and Final Reading
topicSummaries.content: The Social Security Amendment Bill, a cornerstone of the government's welfare policy, passed its third and final reading. The legislation introduces non-financial sanctions for beneficiaries who fail to meet their obligations, such as mandatory money management or community work experience, and requires jobseekers to reapply for their benefits every 26 weeks instead of annually. The Government argued the bill empowers people and supports them into work. Opposition parties strongly condemned the bill as punitive, cruel, and a move that will increase poverty and disproportionately harm Māori and vulnerable families.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Louise Upston (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Simply put, our Government believes that people and families are better off in work, our economy is better off when people are in work, and our Government is committed to making this a reality. I commend this bill to the House.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Willie Jackson (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This malicious and spiteful legislation is nothing more than whipping the poor and then charging them for the beating. The Government is, essentially admitting it would rather punch down on our most vulnerable rather than do anything to help them materially improve their lives.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Under Fire for Scrapping Pay Equity Claims
topicSummaries.content: A heated Question Time saw the Government repeatedly challenged over its decision to cancel 33 active pay equity claims, a move affecting an estimated 180,000 workers. The changes also raise the threshold for what qualifies as a female-dominated workforce from 60% to 70%. Ministers defended the decision, stating it makes the system fairer and returns it to its original purpose. However, the Labour opposition accused the government of degrading the rights of women and using urgency to legislate the change primarily to achieve fiscal savings ahead of the budget.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Barbara Edmonds (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Was accounting for the fiscal savings in her Budget the reason why urgency was used to cancel 33 active pay equity claims?

topicSummaries.topic: New Bill to Fast-Track Critical Infrastructure Projects Introduced
topicSummaries.content: The Government introduced the Public Works (Critical Infrastructure) Amendment Bill, aimed at accelerating the land acquisition process for major projects like roads of national significance. The bill proposes replacing landowner objections to the Environment Court with a streamlined submission process directly to the Minister. It also creates new financial incentive payments to encourage landowners to sell early. The government framed the bill as essential for overcoming New Zealand's infrastructure deficit. Te Pāti Māori vehemently opposed the bill, citing the historical pain and land loss inflicted upon Māori through previous versions of the Public Works Act.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Penk (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Our proposed amendments to the Public Works Act, on which I'm speaking right now, will accelerate the delivery of critical infrastructure which is essential for New Zealand's economic growth.

keyExchanges.speaker: Tākuta Ferris (Te Pāti Māori)
keyExchanges.quote: Māori have suffered loss of land from the Crown through the Public Works Act since 1864... Today, they want to show up with this piece of paper and tell me that incentive payments are going to build trust in te iwi Māori, because it's going to fix everything!

topicSummaries.content: The Speaker issued a significant statement regarding the Privileges Committee's recommendation to suspend three members for contempt, for periods of seven and 21 days. He described the recommended punishments as "very severe and are unprecedented in this Parliament," noting no member has been suspended for more than three days since 1854. Highlighting the narrow majority on the committee and his duty to protect minority rights, the Speaker assured the House a full and proper debate would occur on Tuesday before any decision is made.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Shane Jones (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: Just for clarity in terms of the House and those listening and watching, you are expecting a wide-ranging debate, potentially, involving the three people who did not turn up to the Privileges Committee but who may very well be in the House, and you are anticipating that they will put forward their perspectives as to why this punishment is unnecessary or severe?

keyExchanges.speaker: SPEAKER
keyExchanges.quote: Firstly, there is a motion before the House which is debatable, so any member who is legitimately in the House may speak to it. I'm making it clear to the House that it is an amendable motion, and it always has been under the Standing Orders.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Defends Bottom Trawling Against Environmental Concerns
topicSummaries.content: During Question Time, Minister for Oceans and Fisheries Shane Jones robustly defended the practice of bottom trawling against accusations from the Green Party that it is destructive and losing its social license. The Minister argued that with proper management, the techniques used by the New Zealand fishing industry are "relatively harmless" and vital for the economy. He dismissed environmental concerns raised in relation to the Hauraki Gulf and international documentaries as "emotionalism" that should not override science.

keyExchanges.speaker: Teanau Tuiono (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Does the Minister agree that bottom trawling is rapidly losing its social licence due to the destruction it causes to marine habitats and its high emissions profile, and, if not, why not?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Shane Jones (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: No. The bottom trawling techniques that are pursued by the New Zealand fishing industry are relatively harmless, and I hope the member isn't following catastrophisation of what may happen in less enlightened nations.

conclusion: The government successfully advanced its legislative agenda on welfare and infrastructure, while fending off intense scrutiny over its controversial changes to pay equity laws.
